issue.title: Removing unused catch params breaks JS on older Apple devices
issue.body:
Hi, thanks for all your hard work!

I noticed you recently removed try/catch params if there are no parameter bindings: https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/2e77ff31bcd4eab25e4afc058c4a521384be68b0

This produces statements like this:
```javascript
try {
   1/0
} catch {
   console.log('Oops!')
}
```

This code is valid in most browsers, but not in older Apple devices (Safari on desktop or iPhones / iPads).  So far this is the only incompatibility I've noticed when minifying JS for these platforms, and my only workaround is to explicitly reference the parameter so the minifier doesn't drop the param.

Here's what it looks like in a Safari console:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/266265/199272097-2f117487-0f4d-40ed-b3d0-08935ce34c69.png)

I'm not sure what level of compatibility you're aiming for, but if we could put this behind a flag or handle it differently, that would be great!

I am a Go developer, so if you'd like a PR, just let me know what path you'd like to go down.

comment.body: Thanks for the issue, this should now be fixed by passing the `Version = 2018` option to the JS minifier.

issue.title: Fix background-position minification
issue.body: Fixes #221: order of converted numbers for `background-position: top right`, `bottom left`, `top center`, `bottom center`; disables incorrect conversion for `background-position: top` and `background-position: bottom`.

comment.body:
Thanks, I see what the problem is. This is a minimal reproducible example:
```
background-position:center left  =>  background-position:0 50%
```

That is because the first value should be the X axis and the second the Y. That means that `center left` is valid, but when no keywords are used the order should be reversed.

issue.title: panic in RichText.ToText on initial and consecutive newlines
issue.body:
Calling `Context.DrawText` with a `TextBox` containing a newline at the start of the text string, or multiple newlines in a row, results in a panic due to an index out of range error.

The offending line is [here](https://github.com/tdewolff/canvas/blob/6bed7f464e8fc4ae2a3249ac010ec98d6f0ba716/text.go#L447) - apparently `t.lines[j].spans` ends up being `nil` here.

MWE:
```go
func TestTextBox(t *testing.T) {
	c := canvas.New(100, 100)
	ctx := canvas.NewContext(c)
	font, err := canvas.LoadFontFile("/usr/share/fonts/liberation/LiberationSans-Bold.ttf", canvas.FontRegular)
	if err != nil {
		t.Fatal(err)
	}
	face := font.Face(12, canvas.Black)
	//ctx.DrawText(0, 0, canvas.NewTextBox(face, "\ntext", 100, 100, canvas.Left, canvas.Top, 0, 0))
	ctx.DrawText(0, 0, canvas.NewTextBox(face, "text\n\ntext2", 100, 100, canvas.Left, canvas.Top, 0, 0))
}
```

pull_request.title: JS: add ast JSWriteTo method
pull_request.body:
I often edit ast, modify some data, and then convert ast back to js code, ast.JS() is too slow and takes up a lot of memory

Using buffers can greatly improve efficiency

```
BenchmarkJsAstJSWriteTo-2        10           194873291 ns/op      36253063 B/op    1031732 allocs/op
BenchmarkJsAstJS-2               10          1559868949 ns/op    2160659760 B/op    1057158 allocs/op
```

```go
// JSWriteTo
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
var buf bytes.Buffer
ast.JSWriteTo(&buf)

// JS
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
ast.JS()
```

If this is useful, consider this pr

commits.message: take abs of determinant before square rooting

Merge pull request #188 from TheFoundryVisionmongers/fix-stroke-scaling

fix stroke width scaling being NaN with CartesianIV

pull_request.title: fix stroke width scaling being NaN with CartesianIV
pull_request.body:
When using `CartesianIV` as your coordinate system, you end up with a translation matrix that looks like
```
[[1 0]
 [0 -1]]
```
which has a negative determinant. This PR takes the absolute value of the determinant before calculating the square root to avoid the scaling of the stroke width becoming `NaN`.

issue.title: Writing to a file doesn't wait for the file to be written to before returning
issue.body:
If you have any canvas, then try writing the data to a PNG (I'm guessing this will also happen with other data types) with this code:

```GO
renderers.Write("<PATH>", c)
```

The function will return before the file has been written to. This is a problem for me since I am connecting this with a webserver, so am receiving both `ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE` and `ERR_CONTENT_LENGTH_MISMATCH` errors some of the time. The way I can fix this currently is to add a very small delay between the function returning and the webserver responding with an image, but this isn't ideal.

Would it be possible to either make the function return once the file is written, or add some kind of option to allow it?

comment.body: Thanks for the follow-up, indeed `canvas` closes the file before returning, so it must be a problem at the webserver side.

issue.title: Fast js detection

comment.body:
Hi tmr,

Thank you for writing to me. As you can read in the issue, this is not a
problem of the lexer or parser, but rather a property of the JS language.
You cannot lex a JS source code without also parsing it. You can use a rule
that is 99% of the time correct (see the original JS parser, or the one
from Douglas Crockford (http://www.crockford.com/jsmin.html) , but if you
want to be 100% of the time correct you need to properly parse JS. What I
don't understand is when you refer to slow or fast, what has speed to do
with the issue?

Saludos cordiales,
Taco de Wolff


On Tue, Oct 11, 2022 at 4:49 AM tmr ***@***.***> wrote:

> I use js.Parser to detect if some string is js code, but it's slow again
> for me
>
> I tried using js.Lexer, but that doesn't seem to work, I'm getting regex
> parsing errors, see some related issues, like #72
> <https://github.com/tdewolff/parse/issues/72>, regex seems very difficult
> to handle in Lexer
>
> I would like to ask is there any way to simplify js.Parser to detect js
> and make it faster
>
> // works, but too slowfunc JsDetect(body []byte) bool {
> 	_, err := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
> 	return err == nil
> }
>
> // hope it works, but nofunc JsDetect2(body []byte) bool {
> 	l := js.NewLexer(parse.NewInputBytes(body))
> 	for {
> 		tt, _ := l.Next()
> 		switch tt {
> 		case js.ErrorToken:
> 			if l.Err() != io.EOF {
> 				return false
> 			} else {
> 				return true
> 			}
> 		}
> 	}
> }
>

issue.title: Regression in template literals in 2.12.2
issue.body:
There was a regression introduced in https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/6923a736f60b83d3274ddec7d402a62624d3801f

Having `foo.js`:
```js
const foo = 'hello world';
console.log(`$${foo}`);
```

```
$ node foo.js
$hello world
```

With `minify@2.12.1`:

```
./minify --mime application/javascript foo.js | node
$hello world
```

Under `minify@2.12.3`:

```
./minify --mime application/javascript foo.js | node
`hello world
```

comment.body: Thanks for the issue, found another related bug and fixed both.

GOGCCFLAGS="-fPIC -m64 -pthread -Wl,--no-gc-sections -fmessage-length=0 -fdebug-prefix-map=/tmp/go-build3914674171=/tmp/go-build -gno-record-gcc-switches"
### What did you do? See https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/issues/535 for a bug report and how to reproduce. It concerns the Python binding for a library (https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/tree/master/bindings/py), which can be installed as `pip install tdewolff-minify`. Then running `python test.py` where `test.py` contains: ```python import multiprocessing import minify def minify_worker(number): minify.string('text/html', f"

{number}

"*10000) print(".", end="", flush=True) if __name__ == "__main__": number_list = range(0, 1000) processing_pool = multiprocessing.Pool() processing_pool.map(minify_worker, number_list) print("Done!") ``` This hangs, but when running `GOGC=off python test.py` it works fine. Actually, calling `runtime.GC()` directly in the library causes a hang, suggesting that the garbage collector is responsible for hanging. Note that when using multiprocessing with Python, library function calls are put on a different thread from the one that initialized the Go package (`init()`). What is causing the GC to hang? How can this be debugged?

### What did you do? See https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/issues/535 for a bug report and how to reproduce. It concerns the Python binding for a library (https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/tree/master/bindings/py), which can be installed as `pip install tdewolff-minify`. Then running `python test.py` where `test.py` contains: ```python import multiprocessing import minify def minify_worker(number): minify.string('text/html', f"

{number}

"*10000) print(".", end="", flush=True) if __name__ == "__main__": number_list = range(0, 1000) processing_pool = multiprocessing.Pool() processing_pool.map(minify_worker, number_list) print("Done!") ``` This hangs, but when running `GOGC=off python test.py` it works fine. Actually, calling `runtime.GC()` directly in the library causes a hang, suggesting that the garbage collector is responsible for hanging. Note that when using multiprocessing with Python, library function calls are put on a different thread from the one that initialized the Go package (`init()`). What is causing the GC to hang? How can this be debugged?

comment.body: This seems to be an issue with forking a Go thread. Since Go launches an additional thread for the GC, when forking the main thread the other GC thread is not forked as well, causing it to hang when a forked thread tries to reach the GC thread of the original process. The solution is to not fork Go, but use the spawn strategy for example.

issue.title: concat with filter
issue.body: Is it possible to extend the bundle functionality with a filter so that only functions with a special annotation (e.g. @bundle desktop or @bundle mobile) are bundled to a file. With that it would be possible to annotate functions which are related to desktop, mobile, ... and bundle them later to one file. This would enable one to create smaller bundles for different use cases but write related code in one file. For that you need to parse the content of the files which of course slow down the bundle time. However, the slower performance would buy some flexibility.

issue.title: JS binding segfaults in worker thread
issue.body:
From #379: the worker test case fails due to a race condition. Even when calling an empty function in Go it fails. It gets stuck at `worker.terminate()` when calling `runtime.GC()` in the clean up function. Looks like something we need to take up with Go or with Node.

> Ah no, the os.Exit is terminating the whole node process: https://github.com/dotcore64/rollup-plugin-tdewolff-minify/runs/7272307346?check_suite_focus=true
> It is exiting after the first test...

comment.body:
This has likely to do with a very similar issue with the Python binding, see https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/issues/535#issuecomment-1256793958

Basically, Go cannot be forked since it will only fork the main thread and not the GC thread. The forked threads from the main thread then hang when trying to garbage collect. For some reason, the fix is quite the inverse: for Python we should load the library in each thread (or use the spawning instead of the forking strategy). For JS we need to load the library globally and call its functions in each thread, apparently the `await import` of the same library does only initialize it once (the GC thread) but keeps running on different forked threads.

issue.title: Python binding hangs in forked process
issue.body:
When using the Python bindings with multiprocessing (forking the process via a Pool, to parallelize the minify work), minify appears to hang.

In particular, this seems to happen when minify is imported via the main process, prior to forking the new processes.

A workaround is to ensure that the library doesn't get imported prior to forking (i.e., have the new forked processes perform the import).

I'm not sure if there's any easy library change to fix this, but I at least wanted to let others know of the workaround. 

--

I'm using Python3.10.4; the installed go version is go1.17.1; Ubuntu 22.04.1.

comment.body: Yes, I can confirm this. Adding `multiprocessing.set_start_method('spawn')` before calling `Pool()` prevents hanging.

issue.title: cmd mistakenly running on TS Files, not input file only
issue.body:
My directory structure is a flat tree with source .ts files.  These .ts files get combined into script.js by `tsc`.  My goal is to have `minify` watch the  script.js file and minify it to `script.min.js` in the same directory.

When I run `minify -w -v -o website/static/js/script.min.js website/static/js/script.js`, I get output like "copy website\static\js\common.ts to website\static\js\script.min.js" showing that `minify` is running on a change to the common.ts file.  However, `minify` should only be running on changes to the script.js file per the command.  To confirm `minify` is running on (and copying) .ts files, I can see that the script.js file contains the .ts file's contents for a brief time until `tsc` completes, `minify` notices the updated script.js, and the minifies it.

issue.title: Running Twice/Duplicate On Windows
issue.body:
I have two minify commands, one each watching my script.js and styles.css file.  I am using `-w` for watching for changes to run the minification.  On Windows (10), the minification is run twice for each save of the non-minified file.  This occurs for both JS and CSS. 
 How do I know this? When using `-v` for verbose logging, the `INFO:` line is output twice; once with, usually, near 0 runtime and Inf MB/s speed, and the second with a realistic time and speed.

I have the same repo, go version, and minify version on macOS and the minification only runs once per file save, so this looks like a strictly Windows issue.

This does not impact performance or the actual minifying, it is just odd that minifying occurs twice.  It does not seem like just a logging bug either since sometimes the output does show a slight amount of time used by the "first run".

Example of logging output:
```
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.7102ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  80 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (    569µs,    0 B, 100.0%,    0 B/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.8865ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  79 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (15.6304ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  85 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
```

I tried to dig into the source code a bit but didn't have much luck (or time) in hunting down a cause.  I suspect there is something funky going on with how Windows reports file saves but I am not sure.

---

go version 1.19 (for both Windows and macOS).
Windows 10, macOS macOS Big Sur.
Latest minify (installed via go install github.com/tdewolff/minify/cmd/minify@latest).

Commands: 
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/js/script.min.js website/static/js/script.js`
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/css/styles.min.css website/static/css/styles.css`

comment.body: Yes, the `v2` part bit me today as well trying to install another CLI. Thanks for the effort, closing issue now ;-)

issue.title: concat with filter
issue.body: Is it possible to extend the bundle functionality with a filter so that only functions with a special annotation (e.g. @bundle desktop or @bundle mobile) are bundled to a file. With that it would be possible to annotate functions which are related to desktop, mobile, ... and bundle them later to one file. This would enable one to create smaller bundles for different use cases but write related code in one file. For that you need to parse the content of the files which of course slow down the bundle time. However, the slower performance would buy some flexibility.

comment.body: Thanks for the suggestion. Unfortunately the bundling feature of `minify` is fairly basic and limited (it concatenates files) and there is no roadmap to implement a more advanced bundler. I think your best bet is to put the special annotated functions in different files...

issue.title: Torch.onnx.export is very slow for my neural network - 8 hours for a 39M file

labels.name: module: onnx
labels.description: Related to torch.onnx

labels.name: triaged
labels.description: This issue has been looked at a team member, and triaged and prioritized into an appropriate module

labels.description: needs information from the author / reporter before ONNX team can take action

issue.body:
## 🐛 Bug

I tried to export a PyTorch model in the `.pth` format to `.onnx`, according to this tutorial (https://pytorch.org/tutorials/advanced/super_resolution_with_onnxruntime.html).

My model has ~6.7 million parameters and is 28MB on disk - that's not so big. torchinfo output:
```
===============================================================================================
Layer (type:depth-idx)                        Output Shape              Param #
===============================================================================================
OpenUnmix                                     --                        --
Total params: 6,669,912
Trainable params: 6,669,912
Non-trainable params: 0
Total mult-adds (G): 194.27
===============================================================================================
Input size (MB): 28.63
Forward/backward pass size (MB): 9359.33
Params size (MB): 26.68
Estimated Total Size (MB): 9414.64
```

However, it took 8 hours to export to a 39M ONNX file:
```
(umx-gpu-numba) sevagh:xumx-sliCQ $ ls -latrh xumx_slicq.onnx
-rw-r--r--. 1 sevagh sevagh 39M Jul 29 04:28 xumx_slicq.onnx
```

 Here's my original bug report: https://discuss.pytorch.org/t/torch-onnx-export-of-pytorch-model-is-slow-expected-completion-time/127979 

Strace shows that there is activity occuring throughout the full 8 hour operation:
```
pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb300000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb7c0000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb800000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb700000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb380000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb180000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] mmap(NULL, 262144, PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE, MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS, -1, 0) = 0x7fb9bb8c0000
[pid 238336] mmap(NULL, 262144, PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE, MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS, -1, 0) = 0x7fb9bb880000
[pid 238336] mmap(NULL, 262144, PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE, MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS, -1, 0) = 0x7fb9bb800000
[pid 238336] mmap(NULL, 262144, PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE, MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS, -1, 0) = 0x7fb9bb7c0000
```

The verbose output of the export function showed the following:
```
%247701 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={0}]()
  %247702 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={1}]()
  %247703 : Long(1, device=cpu) = onnx::Range(%247701, %247700, %247702)
  %247704 : Long(4, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Shape(%247669)
  %247705 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={3}]()
  %247706 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Gather[axis=0](%247704, %247705)
  %247707 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Cast[to=7](%247706)
  %247708 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={0}]()
  %247709 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={1}]()
  %247710 : Long(644, device=cpu) = onnx::Range(%247708, %247707, %247709)
  %247712 : Long(1, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Unsqueeze[axes=[0]](%247670)
  %247713 : Long(1, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Unsqueeze[axes=[0]](%247671)
  %247715 : Long(1, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={1}]()
  %247716 : Long(184, device=cpu) = onnx::Slice(%247710, %247712, %247713, %263646, %247715)
  %247717 : Long(4, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value=-1  1  1  1 [ CPULongType{4} ]]()
  %247718 : Long(1, 1, 1, 1, strides=[1, 1, 1, 1], device=cpu) = onnx::Reshape(%247689, %247717)
  %247719 : Long(3, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value=-1  1  1 [ CPULongType{3} ]]()
  %247720 : Long(2, 1, 1, strides=[1, 1, 1], device=cpu) = onnx::Reshape(%247696, %247719)
  %247721 : Long(2, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value=-1  1 [ CPULongType{2} ]]()
  %247722 : Long(1, 1, strides=[1, 1], device=cpu) = onnx::Reshape(%247703, %247721)
  %247723 : Long(1, 2, 1, 1, strides=[2, 1, 1, 1], device=cpu) = onnx::Add(%247718, %247720)
  %247724 : Long(1, 2, 1, 1, strides=[2, 1, 1, 1], device=cpu) = onnx::Add(%247723, %247722)
```

## To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Clone my neural network xumx-sliCQ repository: https://github.com/sevagh/xumx-sliCQ
2. Git-lfs fetch to get the pretrained model downloaded from GitHub LFS
3. Set up the conda environment: https://github.com/sevagh/xumx-sliCQ#training-and-inference 
4. Run the onnx export script on the pretrained `.pth` model to conver to a .onnx file: 
```
(xumx-slicq-gpu) sevagh:xumx-sliCQ $ ./scripts/onnx_export_demo.py ./pretrained-model/
Starting export to onnx...
```

## Expected behavior

I expect this to complete in under 8 hours. @ptrblck recommended that I open a GitHub issue if this is reproducible, and that 8 hours isn't normal.

## Environment

```

comment.body: I meant the opset version, see https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/onnx.html#torch.onnx.export. It defaults to 13 but with 16 it was working fine for me.

1. Clone my neural network xumx-sliCQ repository: https://github.com/sevagh/xumx-sliCQ
2. Git-lfs fetch to get the pretrained model downloaded from GitHub LFS
3. Set up the conda environment: https://github.com/sevagh/xumx-sliCQ#training-and-inference 
4. Run the onnx export script on the pretrained `.pth` model to conver to a .onnx file: 
```

I expect this to complete in under 8 hours. @ptrblck recommended that I open a GitHub issue if this is reproducible, and that 8 hours isn't normal.

issue.title: Running Twice/Duplicate On Windows
issue.body:
I have two minify commands, one each watching my script.js and styles.css file.  I am using `-w` for watching for changes to run the minification.  On Windows (10), the minification is run twice for each save of the non-minified file.  This occurs for both JS and CSS. 
 How do I know this? When using `-v` for verbose logging, the `INFO:` line is output twice; once with, usually, near 0 runtime and Inf MB/s speed, and the second with a realistic time and speed.

I have the same repo, go version, and minify version on macOS and the minification only runs once per file save, so this looks like a strictly Windows issue.

This does not impact performance or the actual minifying, it is just odd that minifying occurs twice.  It does not seem like just a logging bug either since sometimes the output does show a slight amount of time used by the "first run".

Example of logging output:
```
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.7102ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  80 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (    569µs,    0 B, 100.0%,    0 B/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.8865ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  79 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (15.6304ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  85 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
```

I tried to dig into the source code a bit but didn't have much luck (or time) in hunting down a cause.  I suspect there is something funky going on with how Windows reports file saves but I am not sure.

---

go version 1.19 (for both Windows and macOS).
Windows 10, macOS macOS Big Sur.
Latest minify (installed via go install github.com/tdewolff/minify/cmd/minify@latest).

Commands: 
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/js/script.min.js website/static/js/script.js`
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/css/styles.min.css website/static/css/styles.css`

comment.body: Those sound like some really old changes, when running `minify --version`, what does the one return with which you wrote this issue?

comment.body: Yes, great point. There should be a delay of 100ms per file from the last change before minifying to make sure that all intermediate write actions have completed. However, this has already been implemented! Every time a change happens (write, create, ...), minify waits 100ms before minifying. I have no clue as to why this is not sufficient in your case. Either it takes longer than 100ms (is the file very big?) or some other file renaming trick is happening...

issue.title: “\n” not minified in inside backticks
issue.body:
First, I found it cool that minify minifies `\n` – then I noticed some inconsistencies. When running the following through minify,  (e.g. on the web page https://go.tacodewolff.nl/minify):

    console.log('\n', `\n`)

I get

    console.log(`
    `,`\n`)

But I expected to get:

    console.log(`
    `,`
    `)

The `\n` occurring in the backtick quote is never minified. (While the one which was in a single quote to begin with is turned into a backtick quote and minified, just like one would expect.)

comment.body: Great observation, I've implemented proper minification of template literals. Thanks!

issue.title: How to fill a canvas with a loaded image?
issue.body:
I am using `ctx.DrawImage(0, 0, bimg, canvas.DefaultResolution)` to draw the image. But I want to fill the image to the canvas size. Is it possible to achieve it? How?

_I'm sorry I am asking a help in issues. But I didn't find any other mode where I can ask for help._

comment.body: Hi Joseph, that depends on the size of the image and the size of the canvas. I've added a method `canvas.FitImage` to the library that should help in your case! See the commit above.

issue.title: Removing unused catch params breaks JS on older Apple devices
issue.body:
Hi, thanks for all your hard work!

I noticed you recently removed try/catch params if there are no parameter bindings: https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/2e77ff31bcd4eab25e4afc058c4a521384be68b0

This produces statements like this:
```javascript
try {
   1/0
} catch {
   console.log('Oops!')
}
```

This code is valid in most browsers, but not in older Apple devices (Safari on desktop or iPhones / iPads).  So far this is the only incompatibility I've noticed when minifying JS for these platforms, and my only workaround is to explicitly reference the parameter so the minifier doesn't drop the param.

Here's what it looks like in a Safari console:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/266265/199272097-2f117487-0f4d-40ed-b3d0-08935ce34c69.png)

I'm not sure what level of compatibility you're aiming for, but if we could put this behind a flag or handle it differently, that would be great!

I am a Go developer, so if you'd like a PR, just let me know what path you'd like to go down.

comment.body: Thanks for the issue, this should now be fixed by passing the `Version = 2018` option to the JS minifier.

issue.body: Fixes #221: order of converted numbers for `background-position: top right`, `bottom left`, `top center`, `bottom center`; disables incorrect conversion for `background-position: top` and `background-position: bottom`.

comment.body:
Thanks, I see what the problem is. This is a minimal reproducible example:
```
background-position:center left  =>  background-position:0 50%
```

That is because the first value should be the X axis and the second the Y. That means that `center left` is valid, but when no keywords are used the order should be reversed.

issue.title: panic in RichText.ToText on initial and consecutive newlines
issue.body:
Calling `Context.DrawText` with a `TextBox` containing a newline at the start of the text string, or multiple newlines in a row, results in a panic due to an index out of range error.

The offending line is [here](https://github.com/tdewolff/canvas/blob/6bed7f464e8fc4ae2a3249ac010ec98d6f0ba716/text.go#L447) - apparently `t.lines[j].spans` ends up being `nil` here.

MWE:
```go
func TestTextBox(t *testing.T) {
	c := canvas.New(100, 100)
	ctx := canvas.NewContext(c)
	font, err := canvas.LoadFontFile("/usr/share/fonts/liberation/LiberationSans-Bold.ttf", canvas.FontRegular)
	if err != nil {
		t.Fatal(err)
	}
	face := font.Face(12, canvas.Black)
	//ctx.DrawText(0, 0, canvas.NewTextBox(face, "\ntext", 100, 100, canvas.Left, canvas.Top, 0, 0))
	ctx.DrawText(0, 0, canvas.NewTextBox(face, "text\n\ntext2", 100, 100, canvas.Left, canvas.Top, 0, 0))
}

pull_request.title: JS: add ast JSWriteTo method
pull_request.body:
I often edit ast, modify some data, and then convert ast back to js code, ast.JS() is too slow and takes up a lot of memory

Using buffers can greatly improve efficiency

```
BenchmarkJsAstJSWriteTo-2        10           194873291 ns/op      36253063 B/op    1031732 allocs/op
BenchmarkJsAstJS-2               10          1559868949 ns/op    2160659760 B/op    1057158 allocs/op
```

```go
// JSWriteTo
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
var buf bytes.Buffer
ast.JSWriteTo(&buf)

// JS
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
ast.JS()
```

If this is useful, consider this pr

commits.message: take abs of determinant before square rooting

Merge pull request #188 from TheFoundryVisionmongers/fix-stroke-scaling

fix stroke width scaling being NaN with CartesianIV

pull_request.title: fix stroke width scaling being NaN with CartesianIV
pull_request.body:
When using `CartesianIV` as your coordinate system, you end up with a translation matrix that looks like
```
[[1 0]
 [0 -1]]
```
which has a negative determinant. This PR takes the absolute value of the determinant before calculating the square root to avoid the scaling of the stroke width becoming `NaN`.

issue.title: Writing to a file doesn't wait for the file to be written to before returning
issue.body:
If you have any canvas, then try writing the data to a PNG (I'm guessing this will also happen with other data types) with this code:

```GO
renderers.Write("<PATH>", c)
```

The function will return before the file has been written to. This is a problem for me since I am connecting this with a webserver, so am receiving both `ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE` and `ERR_CONTENT_LENGTH_MISMATCH` errors some of the time. The way I can fix this currently is to add a very small delay between the function returning and the webserver responding with an image, but this isn't ideal.

Would it be possible to either make the function return once the file is written, or add some kind of option to allow it?

comment.body: Thanks for the follow-up, indeed `canvas` closes the file before returning, so it must be a problem at the webserver side.

issue.title: Fast js detection

comment.body:
Hi tmr,

Thank you for writing to me. As you can read in the issue, this is not a
problem of the lexer or parser, but rather a property of the JS language.
You cannot lex a JS source code without also parsing it. You can use a rule
that is 99% of the time correct (see the original JS parser, or the one
from Douglas Crockford (http://www.crockford.com/jsmin.html) , but if you
want to be 100% of the time correct you need to properly parse JS. What I
don't understand is when you refer to slow or fast, what has speed to do
with the issue?

Saludos cordiales,
Taco de Wolff


On Tue, Oct 11, 2022 at 4:49 AM tmr ***@***.***> wrote:

> I use js.Parser to detect if some string is js code, but it's slow again
> for me
>
> I tried using js.Lexer, but that doesn't seem to work, I'm getting regex
> parsing errors, see some related issues, like #72
> <https://github.com/tdewolff/parse/issues/72>, regex seems very difficult
> to handle in Lexer
>
> I would like to ask is there any way to simplify js.Parser to detect js
> and make it faster
>
> // works, but too slowfunc JsDetect(body []byte) bool {
> 	_, err := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
> 	return err == nil
> }
>
> // hope it works, but nofunc JsDetect2(body []byte) bool {
> 	l := js.NewLexer(parse.NewInputBytes(body))
> 	for {
> 		tt, _ := l.Next()
> 		switch tt {
> 		case js.ErrorToken:
> 			if l.Err() != io.EOF {
> 				return false
> 			} else {
> 				return true
> 			}
> 		}
> 	}
> }

issue.title: Regression in template literals in 2.12.2
issue.body:
There was a regression introduced in https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/6923a736f60b83d3274ddec7d402a62624d3801f

Having `foo.js`:
```js
const foo = 'hello world';
console.log(`$${foo}`);
```

```
$ node foo.js
$hello world
```

With `minify@2.12.1`:

```
./minify --mime application/javascript foo.js | node
$hello world
```

Under `minify@2.12.3`:

```
./minify --mime application/javascript foo.js | node
`hello world
```

comment.body: Thanks for the issue, found another related bug and fixed both.

### What did you do? See https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/issues/535 for a bug report and how to reproduce. It concerns the Python binding for a library (https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/tree/master/bindings/py), which can be installed as `pip install tdewolff-minify`. Then running `python test.py` where `test.py` contains: ```python import multiprocessing import minify def minify_worker(number): minify.string('text/html', f"

{number}

"*10000) print(".", end="", flush=True) if __name__ == "__main__": number_list = range(0, 1000) processing_pool = multiprocessing.Pool() processing_pool.map(minify_worker, number_list) print("Done!") ``` This hangs, but when running `GOGC=off python test.py` it works fine. comment.body: This seems to be an issue with forking a Go thread. Since Go launches an additional thread for the GC, when forking the main thread the other GC thread is not forked as well, causing it to hang when a forked thread tries to reach the GC thread of the original process. The solution is to not fork Go, but use the spawn strategy for example.

issue.title: concat with filter
issue.body: Is it possible to extend the bundle functionality with a filter so that only functions with a special annotation (e.g. @bundle desktop or @bundle mobile) are bundled to a file. With that it would be possible to annotate functions which are related to desktop, mobile, ... and bundle them later to one file. This would enable one to create smaller bundles for different use cases but write related code in one file. For that you need to parse the content of the files which of course slow down the bundle time. However, the slower performance would buy some flexibility.

issue.title: Option to disable removing trailing skew (or transform) unit
issue.body:
If I have a transform statement like:
```css
transform: skew(20deg,0deg)
```

When I use `minify`, the output is rather:
```css
transform: skew(20deg,0)
```

The lack of the unit in the Y field is causing errors downstream in other tooling, having to go through and replace all `0)`'s with `0deg)` is a bit of a pain 😛

issue.title: JS binding segfaults in worker thread
issue.body:
From #379: the worker test case fails due to a race condition. Even when calling an empty function in Go it fails. It gets stuck at `worker.terminate()` when calling `runtime.GC()` in the clean up function. Looks like something we need to take up with Go or with Node.

> Ah no, the os.Exit is terminating the whole node process: https://github.com/dotcore64/rollup-plugin-tdewolff-minify/runs/7272307346?check_suite_focus=true
> It is exiting after the first test...

comment.body:
This has likely to do with a very similar issue with the Python binding, see https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/issues/535#issuecomment-1256793958

Basically, Go cannot be forked since it will only fork the main thread and not the GC thread. The forked threads from the main thread then hang when trying to garbage collect. For some reason, the fix is quite the inverse: for Python we should load the library in each thread (or use the spawning instead of the forking strategy). For JS we need to load the library globally and call its functions in each thread, apparently the `await import` of the same library does only initialize it once (the GC thread) but keeps running on different forked threads.

issue.title: Python binding hangs in forked process
issue.body:
When using the Python bindings with multiprocessing (forking the process via a Pool, to parallelize the minify work), minify appears to hang.

In particular, this seems to happen when minify is imported via the main process, prior to forking the new processes.

A workaround is to ensure that the library doesn't get imported prior to forking (i.e., have the new forked processes perform the import).

I'm not sure if there's any easy library change to fix this, but I at least wanted to let others know of the workaround. 

--

I'm using Python3.10.4; the installed go version is go1.17.1; Ubuntu 22.04.1.

comment.body: Yes, I can confirm this. Adding `multiprocessing.set_start_method('spawn')` before calling `Pool()` prevents hanging.

issue.title: Python binding hangs in forked process
issue.body:
When using the Python bindings with multiprocessing (forking the process via a Pool, to parallelize the minify work), minify appears to hang.

In particular, this seems to happen when minify is imported via the main process, prior to forking the new processes.

A workaround is to ensure that the library doesn't get imported prior to forking (i.e., have the new forked processes perform the import).

I'm not sure if there's any easy library change to fix this, but I at least wanted to let others know of the workaround. 

--

I'm using Python3.10.4; the installed go version is go1.17.1; Ubuntu 22.04.1.

comment.body: Thank you for the feedback. The JavaScript binding has a very similar problem. I'm not sure if this is a bug in minify itself (I don't think so), or in the bindings themselves (maybe), or in the interaction with Go and Python/JavaScript. It is nonetheless very hard to debug, but since I have a lot more experience in Python than in JS, could you please post a small script that reproduces the issue?

issue.title: Option to disable removing trailing skew (or transform) unit
issue.body:
If I have a transform statement like:
```css
transform: skew(20deg,0deg)
```

When I use `minify`, the output is rather:
```css
transform: skew(20deg,0)
```

The lack of the unit in the Y field is causing errors downstream in other tooling, having to go through and replace all `0)`'s with `0deg)` is a bit of a pain 😛

comment.body: Actually `transform:skew(20deg)` would be an even shorten and valid notation, but both should be valid. The parameters are of type [`<angle>`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/angle) which explicitly states that the unit is optional after the `0`. The other tooling seems to fail to parse valid CSS, would it be possible to raise a bug report there?

issue.title: cmd mistakenly running on TS Files, not input file only
issue.body:
My directory structure is a flat tree with source .ts files.  These .ts files get combined into script.js by `tsc`.  My goal is to have `minify` watch the  script.js file and minify it to `script.min.js` in the same directory.

When I run `minify -w -v -o website/static/js/script.min.js website/static/js/script.js`, I get output like "copy website\static\js\common.ts to website\static\js\script.min.js" showing that `minify` is running on a change to the common.ts file.  However, `minify` should only be running on changes to the script.js file per the command.  To confirm `minify` is running on (and copying) .ts files, I can see that the script.js file contains the .ts file's contents for a brief time until `tsc` completes, `minify` notices the updated script.js, and the minifies it.

So my question is, why is `minify` running on a change to a .ts file if the command specifically notes it should run on changes to script.js?

Complete output is below for a single file change:
```
minify -w -v -o website/static/js/script.min.js website/static/js/script.js 
infer mimetype from file extensions
minify to output file website\static\js\script.min.js

    8: const apiBaseURL: string = "/api/";
                       ^

(19.0289ms, 415 kB, 415 kB, 100.0%,  22 MB/s) - website\static\js\script.min.js
```

issue.title: Running Twice/Duplicate On Windows
issue.body:
I have two minify commands, one each watching my script.js and styles.css file.  I am using `-w` for watching for changes to run the minification.  On Windows (10), the minification is run twice for each save of the non-minified file.  This occurs for both JS and CSS. 
 How do I know this? When using `-v` for verbose logging, the `INFO:` line is output twice; once with, usually, near 0 runtime and Inf MB/s speed, and the second with a realistic time and speed.

I have the same repo, go version, and minify version on macOS and the minification only runs once per file save, so this looks like a strictly Windows issue.

This does not impact performance or the actual minifying, it is just odd that minifying occurs twice.  It does not seem like just a logging bug either since sometimes the output does show a slight amount of time used by the "first run".

Example of logging output:
```
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.7102ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  80 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (    569µs,    0 B, 100.0%,    0 B/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.8865ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  79 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (15.6304ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  85 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
```

I tried to dig into the source code a bit but didn't have much luck (or time) in hunting down a cause.  I suspect there is something funky going on with how Windows reports file saves but I am not sure.

---

go version 1.19 (for both Windows and macOS).
Windows 10, macOS macOS Big Sur.
Latest minify (installed via go install github.com/tdewolff/minify/cmd/minify@latest).

Commands: 
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/js/script.min.js website/static/js/script.js`
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/css/styles.min.css website/static/css/styles.css`

comment.body: Yes, the `v2` part bit me today as well trying to install another CLI. Thanks for the effort, closing issue now ;-)

issue.title: concat with filter
issue.body: Is it possible to extend the bundle functionality with a filter so that only functions with a special annotation (e.g. @bundle desktop or @bundle mobile) are bundled to a file. With that it would be possible to annotate functions which are related to desktop, mobile, ... and bundle them later to one file. This would enable one to create smaller bundles for different use cases but write related code in one file. For that you need to parse the content of the files which of course slow down the bundle time. However, the slower performance would buy some flexibility.

comment.body: Thanks for the suggestion. Unfortunately the bundling feature of `minify` is fairly basic and limited (it concatenates files) and there is no roadmap to implement a more advanced bundler. I think your best bet is to put the special annotated functions in different files...

issue.title: Torch.onnx.export is very slow for my neural network - 8 hours for a 39M file

labels.name: module: onnx
labels.description: Related to torch.onnx

labels.name: triaged
labels.description: This issue has been looked at a team member, and triaged and prioritized into an appropriate module

labels.name: onnx-needs-info
labels.description: needs information from the author / reporter before ONNX team can take action

issue.body:
## 🐛 Bug

I tried to export a PyTorch model in the `.pth` format to `.onnx`, according to this tutorial (https://pytorch.org/tutorials/advanced/super_resolution_with_onnxruntime.html).

My model has ~6.7 million parameters and is 28MB on disk - that's not so big. torchinfo output:
```
===============================================================================================
Layer (type:depth-idx)                        Output Shape              Param #
===============================================================================================
OpenUnmix                                     --                        --
Total params: 6,669,912
Trainable params: 6,669,912
Non-trainable params: 0
Total mult-adds (G): 194.27
===============================================================================================
Input size (MB): 28.63
Forward/backward pass size (MB): 9359.33
Params size (MB): 26.68
Estimated Total Size (MB): 9414.64
```

However, it took 8 hours to export to a 39M ONNX file:
```
(umx-gpu-numba) sevagh:xumx-sliCQ $ ls -latrh xumx_slicq.onnx
-rw-r--r--. 1 sevagh sevagh 39M Jul 29 04:28 xumx_slicq.onnx
```

 Here's my original bug report: https://discuss.pytorch.org/t/torch-onnx-export-of-pytorch-model-is-slow-expected-completion-time/127979 

Strace shows that there is activity occuring throughout the full 8 hour operation:
```
pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb300000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb7c0000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb800000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb700000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb380000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] munmap(0x7fb9bb180000, 262144) = 0
[pid 238336] mmap(NULL, 262144, PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE, MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS, -1, 0) = 0x7fb9bb8c0000
[pid 238336] mmap(NULL, 262144, PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE, MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS, -1, 0) = 0x7fb9bb880000
[pid 238336] mmap(NULL, 262144, PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE, MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS, -1, 0) = 0x7fb9bb800000
[pid 238336] mmap(NULL, 262144, PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE, MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS, -1, 0) = 0x7fb9bb7c0000
```

The verbose output of the export function showed the following:
```
%247701 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={0}]()
  %247702 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={1}]()
  %247703 : Long(1, device=cpu) = onnx::Range(%247701, %247700, %247702)
  %247704 : Long(4, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Shape(%247669)
  %247705 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={3}]()
  %247706 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Gather[axis=0](%247704, %247705)
  %247707 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Cast[to=7](%247706)
  %247708 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={0}]()
  %247709 : Long(device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={1}]()
  %247710 : Long(644, device=cpu) = onnx::Range(%247708, %247707, %247709)
  %247712 : Long(1, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Unsqueeze[axes=[0]](%247670)
  %247713 : Long(1, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Unsqueeze[axes=[0]](%247671)
  %247715 : Long(1, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value={1}]()
  %247716 : Long(184, device=cpu) = onnx::Slice(%247710, %247712, %247713, %263646, %247715)
  %247717 : Long(4, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value=-1  1  1  1 [ CPULongType{4} ]]()
  %247718 : Long(1, 1, 1, 1, strides=[1, 1, 1, 1], device=cpu) = onnx::Reshape(%247689, %247717)
  %247719 : Long(3, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value=-1  1  1 [ CPULongType{3} ]]()
  %247720 : Long(2, 1, 1, strides=[1, 1, 1], device=cpu) = onnx::Reshape(%247696, %247719)
  %247721 : Long(2, strides=[1], device=cpu) = onnx::Constant[value=-1  1 [ CPULongType{2} ]]()
  %247722 : Long(1, 1, strides=[1, 1], device=cpu) = onnx::Reshape(%247703, %247721)
  %247723 : Long(1, 2, 1, 1, strides=[2, 1, 1, 1], device=cpu) = onnx::Add(%247718, %247720)
  %247724 : Long(1, 2, 1, 1, strides=[2, 1, 1, 1], device=cpu) = onnx::Add(%247723, %247722)
```

## To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

issue.title: Running Twice/Duplicate On Windows
issue.body:
I have two minify commands, one each watching my script.js and styles.css file.  I am using `-w` for watching for changes to run the minification.  On Windows (10), the minification is run twice for each save of the non-minified file.  This occurs for both JS and CSS. 
 How do I know this? When using `-v` for verbose logging, the `INFO:` line is output twice; once with, usually, near 0 runtime and Inf MB/s speed, and the second with a realistic time and speed.

I have the same repo, go version, and minify version on macOS and the minification only runs once per file save, so this looks like a strictly Windows issue.

This does not impact performance or the actual minifying, it is just odd that minifying occurs twice.  It does not seem like just a logging bug either since sometimes the output does show a slight amount of time used by the "first run".

Example of logging output:
```
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.7102ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  80 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (    569µs,    0 B, 100.0%,    0 B/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.8865ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  79 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (15.6304ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  85 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
```

I tried to dig into the source code a bit but didn't have much luck (or time) in hunting down a cause.  I suspect there is something funky going on with how Windows reports file saves but I am not sure.

---

go version 1.19 (for both Windows and macOS).
Windows 10, macOS macOS Big Sur.
Latest minify (installed via go install github.com/tdewolff/minify/cmd/minify@latest).

Commands: 
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/js/script.min.js website/static/js/script.js`
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/css/styles.min.css website/static/css/styles.css`

comment.body: Those sound like some really old changes, when running `minify --version`, what does the one return with which you wrote this issue?

comment.body: Yes, great point. There should be a delay of 100ms per file from the last change before minifying to make sure that all intermediate write actions have completed. However, this has already been implemented! Every time a change happens (write, create, ...), minify waits 100ms before minifying. I have no clue as to why this is not sufficient in your case. Either it takes longer than 100ms (is the file very big?) or some other file renaming trick is happening...

issue.title: “\n” not minified in inside backticks
issue.body:
First, I found it cool that minify minifies `\n` – then I noticed some inconsistencies. When running the following through minify,  (e.g. on the web page https://go.tacodewolff.nl/minify):

    console.log('\n', `\n`)

I get

    console.log(`
    `,`\n`)

But I expected to get:

    console.log(`
    `,`
    `)

The `\n` occurring in the backtick quote is never minified. (While the one which was in a single quote to begin with is turned into a backtick quote and minified, just like one would expect.)

comment.body: Great observation, I've implemented proper minification of template literals. Thanks!

issue.title: How to fill a canvas with a loaded image?
issue.body:
I am using `ctx.DrawImage(0, 0, bimg, canvas.DefaultResolution)` to draw the image. But I want to fill the image to the canvas size. Is it possible to achieve it? How?

_I'm sorry I am asking a help in issues. But I didn't find any other mode where I can ask for help._

comment.body: Hi Joseph, that depends on the size of the image and the size of the canvas. I've added a method `canvas.FitImage` to the library that should help in your case! See the commit above.

issue.title: Removing unused catch params breaks JS on older Apple devices
issue.body:
Hi, thanks for all your hard work!

I noticed you recently removed try/catch params if there are no parameter bindings: https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/2e77ff31bcd4eab25e4afc058c4a521384be68b0

This produces statements like this:
```javascript
try {
   1/0
} catch {
   console.log('Oops!')
}
```

This code is valid in most browsers, but not in older Apple devices (Safari on desktop or iPhones / iPads).  So far this is the only incompatibility I've noticed when minifying JS for these platforms, and my only workaround is to explicitly reference the parameter so the minifier doesn't drop the param.

Here's what it looks like in a Safari console:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/266265/199272097-2f117487-0f4d-40ed-b3d0-08935ce34c69.png)

I'm not sure what level of compatibility you're aiming for, but if we could put this behind a flag or handle it differently, that would be great!

I am a Go developer, so if you'd like a PR, just let me know what path you'd like to go down.

comment.body: Thanks for the issue, this should now be fixed by passing the `Version = 2018` option to the JS minifier.

issue.body: Fixes #221: order of converted numbers for `background-position: top right`, `bottom left`, `top center`, `bottom center`; disables incorrect conversion for `background-position: top` and `background-position: bottom`.

comment.body:
Thanks, I see what the problem is. This is a minimal reproducible example:
```
background-position:center left  =>  background-position:0 50%
```

That is because the first value should be the X axis and the second the Y. That means that `center left` is valid, but when no keywords are used the order should be reversed.

issue.title: panic in RichText.ToText on initial and consecutive newlines
issue.body:
Calling `Context.DrawText` with a `TextBox` containing a newline at the start of the text string, or multiple newlines in a row, results in a panic due to an index out of range error.

The offending line is [here](https://github.com/tdewolff/canvas/blob/6bed7f464e8fc4ae2a3249ac010ec98d6f0ba716/text.go#L447) - apparently `t.lines[j].spans` ends up being `nil` here.

MWE:
```go
func TestTextBox(t *testing.T) {
	c := canvas.New(100, 100)
	ctx := canvas.NewContext(c)
	font, err := canvas.LoadFontFile("/usr/share/fonts/liberation/LiberationSans-Bold.ttf", canvas.FontRegular)
	if err != nil {
		t.Fatal(err)
	}
	face := font.Face(12, canvas.Black)
	//ctx.DrawText(0, 0, canvas.NewTextBox(face, "\ntext", 100, 100, canvas.Left, canvas.Top, 0, 0))
	ctx.DrawText(0, 0, canvas.NewTextBox(face, "text\n\ntext2", 100, 100, canvas.Left, canvas.Top, 0, 0))
}
```

pull_request.title: JS: add ast JSWriteTo method
pull_request.body:
I often edit ast, modify some data, and then convert ast back to js code, ast.JS() is too slow and takes up a lot of memory

Using buffers can greatly improve efficiency

```
BenchmarkJsAstJSWriteTo-2        10           194873291 ns/op      36253063 B/op    1031732 allocs/op
BenchmarkJsAstJS-2               10          1559868949 ns/op    2160659760 B/op    1057158 allocs/op
```

```go
// JSWriteTo
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
var buf bytes.Buffer
ast.JSWriteTo(&buf)

// JS
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
ast.JS()
```

If this is useful, consider this pr

commits.message: take abs of determinant before square rooting

Merge pull request #188 from TheFoundryVisionmongers/fix-stroke-scaling

fix stroke width scaling being NaN with CartesianIV

pull_request.title: fix stroke width scaling being NaN with CartesianIV
pull_request.body:
When using `CartesianIV` as your coordinate system, you end up with a translation matrix that looks like
```
[[1 0]
 [0 -1]]
```
which has a negative determinant. This PR takes the absolute value of the determinant before calculating the square root to avoid the scaling of the stroke width becoming `NaN`.

issue.title: Writing to a file doesn't wait for the file to be written to before returning
issue.body:
If you have any canvas, then try writing the data to a PNG (I'm guessing this will also happen with other data types) with this code:

```GO
renderers.Write("<PATH>", c)
```

The function will return before the file has been written to. This is a problem for me since I am connecting this with a webserver, so am receiving both `ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE` and `ERR_CONTENT_LENGTH_MISMATCH` errors some of the time. The way I can fix this currently is to add a very small delay between the function returning and the webserver responding with an image, but this isn't ideal.

Would it be possible to either make the function return once the file is written, or add some kind of option to allow it?

comment.body: Thanks for the follow-up, indeed `canvas` closes the file before returning, so it must be a problem at the webserver side.

issue.title: Fast js detection

comment.body:
Hi tmr,

Thank you for writing to me. As you can read in the issue, this is not a
problem of the lexer or parser, but rather a property of the JS language.
You cannot lex a JS source code without also parsing it. You can use a rule
that is 99% of the time correct (see the original JS parser, or the one
from Douglas Crockford (http://www.crockford.com/jsmin.html) , but if you
want to be 100% of the time correct you need to properly parse JS. What I
don't understand is when you refer to slow or fast, what has speed to do
with the issue?

Saludos cordiales,
Taco de Wolff


On Tue, Oct 11, 2022 at 4:49 AM tmr ***@***.***> wrote:

> I use js.Parser to detect if some string is js code, but it's slow again
> for me
>
> I tried using js.Lexer, but that doesn't seem to work, I'm getting regex
> parsing errors, see some related issues, like #72
> <https://github.com/tdewolff/parse/issues/72>, regex seems very difficult
> to handle in Lexer
>
> I would like to ask is there any way to simplify js.Parser to detect js
> and make it faster
>
> // works, but too slowfunc JsDetect(body []byte) bool {
> 	_, err := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
> 	return err == nil
> }
>
> // hope it works, but nofunc JsDetect2(body []byte) bool {
> 	l := js.NewLexer(parse.NewInputBytes(body))
> 	for {
> 		tt, _ := l.Next()
> 		switch tt {
> 		case js.ErrorToken:
> 			if l.Err() != io.EOF {
> 				return false
> 			} else {
> 				return true
> 			}
> 		}
> 	}
> }
>

issue.title: Regression in template literals in 2.12.2
issue.body:
There was a regression introduced in https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/6923a736f60b83d3274ddec7d402a62624d3801f

Having `foo.js`:
```js
const foo = 'hello world';
console.log(`$${foo}`);
```

```
$ node foo.js
$hello world
```

With `minify@2.12.1`:

```
./minify --mime application/javascript foo.js | node
$hello world
```

Under `minify@2.12.3`:

```
./minify --mime application/javascript foo.js | node
`hello world
```

comment.body: Thanks for the issue, found another related bug and fixed both.

### What did you do? See https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/issues/535 for a bug report and how to reproduce. It concerns the Python binding for a library (https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/tree/master/bindings/py), which can be installed as `pip install tdewolff-minify`. Then running `python test.py` where `test.py` contains: ```python import multiprocessing import minify def minify_worker(number): minify.string('text/html', f"

{number}

"*10000) print(".", end="", flush=True) if __name__ == "__main__": number_list = range(0, 1000) processing_pool = multiprocessing.Pool() processing_pool.map(minify_worker, number_list) print("Done!") ``` This hangs, but when running `GOGC=off python test.py` it works fine. comment.body: This seems to be an issue with forking a Go thread. Since Go launches an additional thread for the GC, when forking the main thread the other GC thread is not forked as well, causing it to hang when a forked thread tries to reach the GC thread of the original process. The solution is to not fork Go, but use the spawn strategy for example.

issue.title: concat with filter
issue.body: Is it possible to extend the bundle functionality with a filter so that only functions with a special annotation (e.g. @bundle desktop or @bundle mobile) are bundled to a file. With that it would be possible to annotate functions which are related to desktop, mobile, ... and bundle them later to one file. This would enable one to create smaller bundles for different use cases but write related code in one file. For that you need to parse the content of the files which of course slow down the bundle time. However, the slower performance would buy some flexibility.

issue.title: Option to disable removing trailing skew (or transform) unit
issue.body:
If I have a transform statement like:

transform: skew(20deg,0deg)

When I use `minify`, the output is rather:

```

The lack of the unit in the Y field is causing errors downstream in other tooling, having to go through and replace all `0)`'s with `0deg)` is a bit of a pain 😛

issue.title: JS binding segfaults in worker thread
issue.body:
From #379: the worker test case fails due to a race condition. Even when calling an empty function in Go it fails. It gets stuck at `worker.terminate()` when calling `runtime.GC()` in the clean up function. Looks like something we need to take up with Go or with Node.

> Ah no, the os.Exit is terminating the whole node process: https://github.com/dotcore64/rollup-plugin-tdewolff-minify/runs/7272307346?check_suite_focus=true
> It is exiting after the first test...

comment.body:
This has likely to do with a very similar issue with the Python binding, see https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/issues/535#issuecomment-1256793958

Basically, Go cannot be forked since it will only fork the main thread and not the GC thread. The forked threads from the main thread then hang when trying to garbage collect. For some reason, the fix is quite the inverse: for Python we should load the library in each thread (or use the spawning instead of the forking strategy). For JS we need to load the library globally and call its functions in each thread, apparently the `await import` of the same library does only initialize it once (the GC thread) but keeps running on different forked threads.

issue.title: Python binding hangs in forked process
issue.body:
When using the Python bindings with multiprocessing (forking the process via a Pool, to parallelize the minify work), minify appears to hang.

In particular, this seems to happen when minify is imported via the main process, prior to forking the new processes.

A workaround is to ensure that the library doesn't get imported prior to forking (i.e., have the new forked processes perform the import).

I'm not sure if there's any easy library change to fix this, but I at least wanted to let others know of the workaround. 

--

I'm using Python3.10.4; the installed go version is go1.17.1; Ubuntu 22.04.1.

comment.body: Yes, I can confirm this. Adding `multiprocessing.set_start_method('spawn')` before calling `Pool()` prevents hanging.

issue.title: Python binding hangs in forked process
issue.body:
When using the Python bindings with multiprocessing (forking the process via a Pool, to parallelize the minify work), minify appears to hang.

In particular, this seems to happen when minify is imported via the main process, prior to forking the new processes.

A workaround is to ensure that the library doesn't get imported prior to forking (i.e., have the new forked processes perform the import).

I'm not sure if there's any easy library change to fix this, but I at least wanted to let others know of the workaround. 

--

I'm using Python3.10.4; the installed go version is go1.17.1; Ubuntu 22.04.1.

comment.body: Thank you for the feedback. The JavaScript binding has a very similar problem. I'm not sure if this is a bug in minify itself (I don't think so), or in the bindings themselves (maybe), or in the interaction with Go and Python/JavaScript. It is nonetheless very hard to debug, but since I have a lot more experience in Python than in JS, could you please post a small script that reproduces the issue?

issue.title: Option to disable removing trailing skew (or transform) unit
issue.body:
If I have a transform statement like:
```css
transform: skew(20deg,0deg)
```

When I use `minify`, the output is rather:
```css
transform: skew(20deg,0)
```

The lack of the unit in the Y field is causing errors downstream in other tooling, having to go through and replace all `0)`'s with `0deg)` is a bit of a pain 😛

comment.body: Actually `transform:skew(20deg)` would be an even shorten and valid notation, but both should be valid. The parameters are of type [`<angle>`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/angle) which explicitly states that the unit is optional after the `0`. The other tooling seems to fail to parse valid CSS, would it be possible to raise a bug report there?

issue.title: cmd mistakenly running on TS Files, not input file only
issue.body:
My directory structure is a flat tree with source .ts files.  These .ts files get combined into script.js by `tsc`.  My goal is to have `minify` watch the  script.js file and minify it to `script.min.js` in the same directory.

When I run `minify -w -v -o website/static/js/script.min.js website/static/js/script.js`, I get output like "copy website\static\js\common.ts to website\static\js\script.min.js" showing that `minify` is running on a change to the common.ts file.  However, `minify` should only be running on changes to the script.js file per the command.  To confirm `minify` is running on (and copying) .ts files, I can see that the script.js file contains the .ts file's contents for a brief time until `tsc` completes, `minify` notices the updated script.js, and the minifies it.

So my question is, why is `minify` running on a change to a .ts file if the command specifically notes it should run on changes to script.js?

Complete output is below for a single file change:

issue.title: Running Twice/Duplicate On Windows
issue.body:
I have two minify commands, one each watching my script.js and styles.css file.  I am using `-w` for watching for changes to run the minification.  On Windows (10), the minification is run twice for each save of the non-minified file.  This occurs for both JS and CSS. 
 How do I know this? When using `-v` for verbose logging, the `INFO:` line is output twice; once with, usually, near 0 runtime and Inf MB/s speed, and the second with a realistic time and speed.

I have the same repo, go version, and minify version on macOS and the minification only runs once per file save, so this looks like a strictly Windows issue.

This does not impact performance or the actual minifying, it is just odd that minifying occurs twice.  It does not seem like just a logging bug either since sometimes the output does show a slight amount of time used by the "first run".

Example of logging output:
```
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.7102ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  80 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (    569µs,    0 B, 100.0%,    0 B/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.8865ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  79 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (15.6304ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  85 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
```

I tried to dig into the source code a bit but didn't have much luck (or time) in hunting down a cause.  I suspect there is something funky going on with how Windows reports file saves but I am not sure.

---

go version 1.19 (for both Windows and macOS).
Windows 10, macOS macOS Big Sur.
Latest minify (installed via go install github.com/tdewolff/minify/cmd/minify@latest).

Commands: 
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/js/script.min.js website/static/js/script.js`
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/css/styles.min.css website/static/css/styles.css`

comment.body: Yes, the `v2` part bit me today as well trying to install another CLI. Thanks for the effort, closing issue now ;-)

issue.title: concat with filter
issue.body: Is it possible to extend the bundle functionality with a filter so that only functions with a special annotation (e.g. @bundle desktop or @bundle mobile) are bundled to a file. With that it would be possible to annotate functions which are related to desktop, mobile, ... and bundle them later to one file. This would enable one to create smaller bundles for different use cases but write related code in one file. For that you need to parse the content of the files which of course slow down the bundle time. However, the slower performance would buy some flexibility.

comment.body: Thanks for the suggestion. Unfortunately the bundling feature of `minify` is fairly basic and limited (it concatenates files) and there is no roadmap to implement a more advanced bundler. I think your best bet is to put the special annotated functions in different files...

issue.title: Torch.onnx.export is very slow for my neural network - 8 hours for a 39M file

labels.name: module: onnx
labels.description: Related to torch.onnx

labels.name: triaged
labels.description: This issue has been looked at a team member, and triaged and prioritized into an appropriate module

labels.name: onnx-needs-info
labels.description: needs information from the author / reporter before ONNX team can take action

issue.body:
## 🐛 Bug

I tried to export a PyTorch model in the `.pth` format to `.onnx`, according to this tutorial (https://pytorch.org/tutorials/advanced/super_resolution_with_onnxruntime.html).

My model has ~6.7 million parameters and is 28MB on disk - that's not so big. torchinfo output:
```
===============================================================================================
Layer (type:depth-idx)                        Output Shape              Param #
===============================================================================================
OpenUnmix                                     --                        --
Total params: 6,669,912
Trainable params: 6,669,912
Non-trainable params: 0
Total mult-adds (G): 194.27
===============================================================================================
Input size (MB): 28.63
Forward/backward pass size (MB): 9359.33
Params size (MB): 26.68
Estimated Total Size (MB): 9414.64
```

However, it took 8 hours to export to a 39M ONNX file:
```
(umx-gpu-numba) sevagh:xumx-sliCQ $ ls -latrh xumx_slicq.onnx

issue.title: Running Twice/Duplicate On Windows
issue.body:
I have two minify commands, one each watching my script.js and styles.css file.  I am using `-w` for watching for changes to run the minification.  On Windows (10), the minification is run twice for each save of the non-minified file.  This occurs for both JS and CSS. 
 How do I know this? When using `-v` for verbose logging, the `INFO:` line is output twice; once with, usually, near 0 runtime and Inf MB/s speed, and the second with a realistic time and speed.

I have the same repo, go version, and minify version on macOS and the minification only runs once per file save, so this looks like a strictly Windows issue.

This does not impact performance or the actual minifying, it is just odd that minifying occurs twice.  It does not seem like just a logging bug either since sometimes the output does show a slight amount of time used by the "first run".

Example of logging output:
```
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.7102ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  80 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (    569µs,    0 B, 100.0%,    0 B/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (16.8865ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  79 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (       0s,    0 B, 100.0%, Inf MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
INFO: (15.6304ms, 461 kB,  34.6%,  85 MB/s) - website/static/js/script.js to website/static/js/script.min.js
```

I tried to dig into the source code a bit but didn't have much luck (or time) in hunting down a cause.  I suspect there is something funky going on with how Windows reports file saves but I am not sure.

---

go version 1.19 (for both Windows and macOS).
Windows 10, macOS macOS Big Sur.
Latest minify (installed via go install github.com/tdewolff/minify/cmd/minify@latest).

Commands: 
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/js/script.min.js website/static/js/script.js`
- `minify -w -v -o website/static/css/styles.min.css website/static/css/styles.css`

comment.body: Those sound like some really old changes, when running `minify --version`, what does the one return with which you wrote this issue?

comment.body: Yes, great point. There should be a delay of 100ms per file from the last change before minifying to make sure that all intermediate write actions have completed. However, this has already been implemented! Every time a change happens (write, create, ...), minify waits 100ms before minifying. I have no clue as to why this is not sufficient in your case. Either it takes longer than 100ms (is the file very big?) or some other file renaming trick is happening...

issue.title: “\n” not minified in inside backticks
issue.body:
First, I found it cool that minify minifies `\n` – then I noticed some inconsistencies. When running the following through minify,  (e.g. on the web page https://go.tacodewolff.nl/minify):

    console.log('\n', `\n`)

I get

    console.log(`
    `,`\n`)

But I expected to get:

    console.log(`
    `,`
    `)

The `\n` occurring in the backtick quote is never minified. (While the one which was in a single quote to begin with is turned into a backtick quote and minified, just like one would expect.)

comment.body: Great observation, I've implemented proper minification of template literals. Thanks!

issue.title: How to fill a canvas with a loaded image?
issue.body:
I am using `ctx.DrawImage(0, 0, bimg, canvas.DefaultResolution)` to draw the image. But I want to fill the image to the canvas size. Is it possible to achieve it? How?

_I'm sorry I am asking a help in issues. But I didn't find any other mode where I can ask for help._

comment.body: Hi Joseph, that depends on the size of the image and the size of the canvas. I've added a method `canvas.FitImage` to the library that should help in your case! See the commit above.

comment.body: Fixed in minify@v2.12.1, thanks for the help @jmooring ! Please wait for a new release of Hugo to get this fixed @FarrelF

release.name: v2.12.1
release.body:
- [JS: set vardecl size limit to prevent timeout with OSSFuzz](https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/e036f968d0214aac7f603a0ef3f332c77fc4b996)
- [Change minify.writer.Writer return type to io.WriteCloser,](https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/f247b7dac0f63755be3cc886d048ec3519683845) [fixes](https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/f247b7dac0f63755be3cc886d048ec3519683845) https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/issues/524
- [JS: support declarations in export default, add syntax errors for variable declarations, fixes https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/issues/525](https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/2d24fc4cc3c0a552de8dcee3ca6f6a0941681b90)
- [JS: fix when parenthesized expr has assignments for the same variable which only when interpreted as arguments for an arrow func should error, fixes https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/issues/528](https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/655ab04237d97ba18c4d153adb40daf20687baf9)
release.short_description_html:
• JS: set vardecl size limit to prevent timeout with OSSFuzz
  • Change minify.writer.Writer return type to io.WriteCloser, fixes #524
  • JS: support declarations in export default, add syntax errors for v…

issue.title: js: New nilpointer
issue.body:
I don't have a simple reproduceable for you, but this issue is pretty informative:

https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/issues/10230

This happened after this deps upgrade:

https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/commit/60ede146b613100286144bd110e697334cab9902
